Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Testing mechanistic connections between sex, foraging and parasitism along an ecological gradient
Award.AbstractNarration:
Individuals of the same species often differ in important traits, and these differences are known functions of genetic and environmental influences. For most species, however, a mechanistic understanding of the origin and maintenance of individual variation is still missing. This project proposes mechanistic connections among three seemingly unrelated traits: investment in sexual versus asexual reproduction, feeding performance on rich versus poor resources, and susceptibility to parasites. The investigators hypothesize that differences in feeding rates create a causal chain of relationships that ultimately promotes the maintenance of diversity through basic ecological mechanisms. To test these ideas, the research combines monitoring of biodiversity and diseases in natural populations with laboratory experiments designed to disentangle genetic versus environmental factors shaping the traits of individuals. By determining how seemingly unrelated traits are integrated into distinct strategies, and examining how the frequency of different strategies varies along a natural ecological gradient, the research will provide novel insights into the ecological pressures maintaining phenotypic and genetic variation in natural populations.

Results from this study will significantly advance understanding of how diseases spread and how biodiversity is maintained. Diverse educational opportunities will be provided for undergraduate students, graduate students, postdoctoral scientists, and research technicians. The investigators will develop a public lecture series, a summer science camp, and a new biology-mathematics course, and support activities focused on recruitment, retention and mentoring of students from under-represented groups.

Collaborative Research: Testing mechanistic connections between sex, foraging, and parasitism along an ecological gradient

 

Individuals of the same species often differ in important traits such as growth rate, vulnerability to disease, and reproductive output. We know that these differences arise as a function of both genetics and environmental influences. However, for most species scientists still lack comprehensive, mechanistic understanding of the creation and maintenance of these differences among individuals. This limitation inhibits our ability to understand questions involving spread of disease and maintenance of biological diversity in nature. To enhance this mechanistic insight, this project studied how microscopic freshwater animals (zooplankton) avoid or contract deadly infectious disease while feeding on their algal resources. The central focus in this project forged new connections between traits that are associated with gathering food resources (e.g., how fast animals feed, how their guts process that food), how they allocate those resources once they have been eaten (to growth, immune system, clonal reproduction, or sexual reproduction), and vulnerability to disease. We also explored how relationships between these traits may influence the maintenance of genetic diversity. To develop and test these ideas, this project combined monitoring of biodiversity and diseases in natural populations in Michigan and Indiana with laboratory experiments for two species of zooplankton.  Our work was designed to disentangle genetic versus environmental factors shaping the traits of individuals. Plankton provide a useful model system for studying these general questions because they are easy to sample from nature, and one can readily quantify their traits in laboratory experiments.

 

In the Indiana portion of this grant, we used a combination of experiments, mathematical models, and observations of disease epidemics to glean a set of insights centered around feeding rate and other resource-relevant traits. Individual genotypes of a focal zooplankton host do show a key tradeoff in their ability to use highly nutritious vs. poorly nutritious food. Some genotypes excel at growing on highly nutritious foods, while others excel at growth on poorer quality (made poor experimentally in a variety of ways). However, in the field, we found that nutrition of resources was always poor, among diverse lakes and through of disease epidemics (autumn). Furthermore, we found that ability to grow on poor resources strongly determines success of a species during disease epidemics when they erupt with competitors of hosts. Fast growers on poor resources do best against disease and competitors, even though these genotypes are more susceptible to disease. However, extremely good competitors could create enormous epidemics after suppressing density of other species that could have helped constrain epidemics. Other factors, such as gut passage time, etc., proved less important (while still interesting physiologically). Second, we discovered that hosts allocate more to sexual reproduction during disease epidemics. This species of host only reproduces sexually as winter approaches. They increase allocation to production of males (necessary for sex) during larger epidemics. We ruled out a 'last man standing' hypothesis: males do not increase in frequency because they resist infection better. Instead, individual females chose to increase production of sons vs. daughters during disease epidemics. Thus, parasites play a role in the ecology and evolution of sex. Third, we found that disease shifts host populations towards higher frequency of juveniles by increasing mortality of more vulnerable adults (and not by delaying development into adults and/or slowing feeding rate of adult hosts). Fourth, this grant funded discovery of a type of "hydra" effect: large epidemics of a parasite that kills its host could actually lead to higher host density due to depression of feeding rates of hosts. Fifth, in an important spin-off project, we developed a statistical and experimental method to separate exposure to parasites (feeding) vs. susceptibility to infection by parasites consumed. Using this technique, we produced important new insights into connections between temperatures and disease. For instance, we found that warmer temperatures make larger disease epidemics by speeding up infection by parasites (and also by increasing production of parasites within hosts). Additionally, we learned that parasite made when warmer are more infectious per parasite. Yet, very warm temperatures could lower this infectiousness and also harm parasites in their environmental phase. Thus, by focusing on feeding rate and disease, the Indiana portion of this collaboration produced new insights into a set of inter-related concepts, including: outcomes of disease epidemics with competitors; allocation of effort to sexual reproduction among populations; shifts in ratios of juveniles to adults in populations (which has implications for how ecosystems function); discovery of a counter-intuitive result (hydra effect) which may help explain why some populations do not suffer catastrophic declines in density during epidemics; and new insights into why warmer temperatures could make host populations sicker (within limits).
